#Text=Georgi Obretenov
#Text=Georgi Tihov Obretenov
#Text=( Bulgarian : Георги Тихов Обретенов ) was a Bulgarian revolutionary , best known for his participation in the April Uprising of 1876 .
#Text=Biography
#Text=Georgi Obretenov , the youngest son of Tonka Obretenova , was born after 1849 .
#Text=He studied in the class school in Rousse , and afterwards helped his father with his business in the village of Isakcha in Northern Dobruja .
#Text=In the spring of 1870 Georgi was admitted to the junker school in Odessa .
#Text=In order to take part in setting the ground for the Stara Zagora uprising of 1875 , he returned to Rousse , and joined the preparations of a detachment 's in Veliko Tarnovo .
#Text=After the uprising 's failure , he moved to Romania .
#Text=The revolutionary committee in Giurgiu estimated Georgi Obretenov 's training and sent him to the region of Sliven as a military instructor and as an assistant apostle to Ilarion Dragostinov .
#Text=Along with the weapons , Obretenov brought to Sliven some revolutionary proclamations , by-laws , a flag , and the inspiring poetry of Hristo Botev and Stefan Stambolov .
#Text=Dragostinov and Obretenov chose different routes to Sliven .
#Text=Dragostinov travelled through Svishtov and Arbanasi , in order to bid farewell to his parents and relatives .
#Text=Obretenov 's route was through Rousse .
#Text=After passing the Balkan mountains , he stayed in Tvarditsa at priest Stefan 's , and hid the dangerous luggage in the altar of the local church .

#Text=Then , he set off to the village of Korten to visit Georgi Kolev , the leader of the local revolutionary committee , with whose help he hid the items he carried in a wheat cart , and they both arrived in Sliven .
#Text=The coming of the two gave new impulse to the preparations in Sliven , though they did n't manage to reach consensus with local activists in terms of tactics .
#Text=The locals ' plan was to adopt a course of preparation of detachments , who were to operate in the Balkan mountains , without exciting a revolt in town .
#Text=This viewpoint dominated , and put an imprint the overall preparatory work , and later on the range and power of the uprising throughout the Sliven region .
#Text=The military instructor , Georgi Obretenov , brought to Sliven modern guns , having issued directions about arms before departing from Giurgiu .
#Text=He wrote that every rebel had to possess a revolver with 200 bullets , a gun with 250 bullets , and a knife .
#Text=Furthermore , each of them was to provide two cartridge-boxes for the bullets .
#Text=Undoubtedly , Obrevenov strived for imposing those requirements on everyone in the Second Revolutionary Region .
#Text=Concerning military action , he gave oral instructions without leaving anything on paper .
#Text=There is information that the leaders of the Sliven revolutionary committee took care to supply modern guns from Romania .
#Text=They grew funds from the rebels ' voluntary donations .
#Text=Obretenov brought to Sliven a flag sewn by his sisters Petrana and Anastasia .
#Text=Therefore , Sliven revolutionaries considered it unnecessary to prepare their own flag .

#Text=The leaders of the rebel group , gathered on " Kush Bunar " — Ilarion Dragostinov , Stoil Voyvoda , Georgi Obretenov , and Georgi Drazhev — decided to execute the adopted plan for touring the Balkan villages in the vicinity of Kotel and exciting a revolt , despite the small number of rebels .
#Text=Attempting to go back for food through Neykovo , the detachment were confronted by bashi-bazouks , regular army , and cherkez cavalry .
#Text=On their way back , they fought , and Obretenov was fatally wounded in the battle .
#Text=On 10 May 1876 , realizing that , he committed suicide .
